bestBHT.bht: The letter sent by the chief captain to Governor Felix is described as containing a specific form or type, possibly similar to a formal report required by Roman law. It is suggested that Paul may have been given a copy of the letter after appealing to Caesar. The letter is seen as a clever combination of truth and falsehood, favoring Lysias and omitting any mention of the order to scourge Paul. The overall purpose of the letter seems to be to present a favorable image of Lysias and to hinder Paul's adversaries from causing him harm.

Marvin Vincent: After this manner [περιεχουσαν τον τυπον τουτον] . Lit., containing this form or type. See on it is contained, 1 Peter 2:6.
John Calvin: First, we must briefly admonish the readers who have not been conversant in histories, that this Felix was brother to Pallas, who being Caesar’s freeman, became equal with the chief of the city in wealth and power.

The sum of the epistle tendeth to this end, that the chief captain may help Paul with his prejudice; and may admonish Felix of the injuries of his adversaries, and may so discredit them, that they may not be able to do him any hurt.
‘Suo praejudicio,’ by bearing previous testimony in his favour.
Archibald T. Robertson: The Roman law required that a subordinate officer like Lysias in reporting a case to his superior should send a written statement of the case and it was termed elogium.
A copy of the letter may have been given Paul after his appeal to Caesar.
The letter is a 'dexterous mixture of truth and falsehood' (Furneaux) with the stamp of genuineness. It puts things in a favourable light for Lysias and makes no mention of his order to scourge Paul.
John Gill: The chief captain wrote a letter to Felix the governor, the form and sum of which were as follow."
This letter he sent by one of the centurions to him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The letter sent by the chief captain to Governor Felix in Acts 23:25 is described as containing a specific form or type, possibly similar to a formal report required by Roman law. It is suggested that Paul may have been given a copy of the letter after appealing to Caesar. The letter is seen as a clever combination of truth and falsehood, favoring Lysias and omitting any mention of the order to scourge Paul. The overall purpose of the letter seems to be to present a favorable image of Lysias and to hinder Paul's adversaries from causing him harm.

The letter sent by the chief captain to Governor Felix is described as containing a specific form or type, possibly similar to a formal report required by Roman law. It is suggested that Paul may have been given a copy of the letter after appealing to Caesar. The letter is seen as a clever combination of truth and falsehood, favoring Lysias and omitting any mention of the order to scourge Paul. The overall purpose of the letter seems to be to present a favorable image of Lysias and to hinder Paul's adversaries from causing him harm.

The letter sent by the chief captain to Governor Felix contains a specific form or type, possibly required by Roman law. It is speculated that Paul may have received a copy of the letter after appealing to Caesar. The letter is considered a skillful blend of truth and falsehood, favoring Lysias and conveniently leaving out the order to scourge Paul. Its purpose seems to be to portray Lysias in a positive light and discredit Paul's adversaries, preventing them from causing harm.

The letter sent to Governor Felix by the chief captain is said to have a specific form or type, possibly required by Roman law. It is speculated that Paul may have received a copy of the letter after appealing to Caesar. The letter is described as a clever mixture of truth and falsehood, favoring Lysias while conveniently omitting any mention of the order to scourge Paul. Its purpose appears to be to present Lysias in a positive light and protect Paul from harm inflicted by his adversaries.

The chief captain's letter to Governor Felix is deemed to have a specific form or type, possibly complying with Roman law. It is implied that Paul might have received a copy following his appeal to Caesar. The letter is seen as a clever amalgamation of truth and falsehood, aiming to favor Lysias and conveniently overlooking the order to scourge Paul. Its purpose is perceived as presenting Lysias favorably and thwarting the intentions of Paul's adversaries to harm him.
